THE BAD BOY MOURNS FOR A DECEASED ROOSTER.

The owner's disappointment and grief at the loss of his favorite rooster was evident in his words.

"I don't think I can take it," said he, "to lose my rooster. He was such a good companion and always seemed to be there when I needed him."

The owner continued, "I'm sure he will be missed by all who knew him. He was a true friend and always there when I needed him."

PRINCE ALBERT - - - N.W.T.
CHURCH NEWS.

On Saturday next the 21st inst., the Rev. W. H. Cooper, F.R.G.S., will be installed as the new rector of Knox Church, where he will give some interesting details in reference to the church work of the past quarter. He will also preach on the subject of "The Church," and will present an admirable sermon on the subject of "Mary's Life and Death." His Lordship, the Bishop, stated that next Sunday there would be a special collection for the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel. He explained that it was not merely a question of money, but that in each Mission helped by the Society, after a disease had been organized and treated, and the patient had been brought back to health, the Society had been able to help the patient in his daily life. Mr. Cooper will also preach on Sunday at 3 p.m., and will give a talk when there will be a special collection for the same purpose. Mr. Cooper is the guest of the Bishop, who has been invited to stay at Knox Church.

On Saturday next, the 21st inst., the interesting ceremony of consecrating the Church of St. John the Baptist at South Branch will be performed by His Lordship, the Bishop of Saskatchewan. The service will be conducted by the Rev. W. H. Cooper, F.R.G.S., who will act as his chaplain on the occasion and will also preach the sermon.

SHIPMENT OF FUR.

The old and reliable Indian trading firm of Stewart, Eden & Co. shipped to Winnipeg on Saturday last, two large shipments of furs, consisting chiefly of otter, beaver, musk, martin, Fisher and a variety of other furs, amounting over 120 packs in all. This firm, which has built up an enviable reputation all over the country, are to be congratulated in having for their agent Mr. James Sinclair, who has been engaged by Mr. John E. Kennedy, whose splendid endeavors in the interests of his employers have done much towards securing such a successful trade in Prince Albert.

SCHOOL EXAMINATION.

The closing examination of Miss Eaton's school took place last week. The results gave evidence of the high degree of ability, earnestness and wonderful tact in the management of children. The average marks obtained last year was 45. The following is the name list:

FIFTH GRADE.
1st, Marion Wilson; 2nd, Mary E. McKay; 3rd, Maggie Finlayson.

6TH GRADE.
1st, Marion Wilson; 2nd, Maggie Finlayson.

7TH GRADE.
General Progress, Blanche Spratt; Recitation and Composition, Maggie McKay; Reading, Maggie McKay; Geography, Willie Macdonald; Writing, Maggie McKay.

8TH GRADE.
First Division—General Progress, Maggie McKay; Arithmetic, Maggie McKay; Reading, Alfred Oram and Willie Macdonald; Writing, Maggie McKay.

The British fur trade is active because of the increased demand from the United States and Canada.

A Dublin dispatch says—Rev. Theo. N. Burk, a well-known priest and lecturer, died suddenly at Limerick. A man named Mr. Lawrence, M. P., bowling green, has been killed by Mr. Donaldson, who was charged with an offence on May 25th.

Mr. A. W. R. Mackay, of the town, and former lumberman, of whom little is known, has died at his residence in Bathurst. They came down the river in a boat and were alone three men and a child on the trip.
